history.content: Thanks for pointing out that the link is broken.  There is indeed a course description though in the catalog. See http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/compsci/

The course catalog description helps a little, but I think the main thing to know about the class is that the material is essentially just some set of advanced topics in machine learning for those who've already gotten the basics down (from 281A). The specific subjects covered are completely up to the instructor, and vary depending on what the instructor's interests are, though there will probably be some topics shared between offerings. Michael Jordan, for example, is quite interested in Bayesian methods and nonparametrics, so he might have a significant focus on those topics.

Examples of previous offerings:

  • Jordan, Spring 2004: http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~jordan/courses/281B-spring04/
  • Wainwright, Spring 2009: http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/~wainwrig/stat241b/
  • Bartlett, Spring 2014: http://www.stat.berkeley.edu/~bartlett/courses/2014spring-cs281bstat241b/

The course catalog description helps a little, but I think the main thing to know about the class is that the material is essentially just some set of advanced topics in machine learning for those who've already gotten the basics down (from 281A). The specific subjects covered are completely up to the instructor, and vary depending on what the instructor's interests are, though there will probably be some topics shared between offerings. Michael Jordan, for example, is quite interested in Bayesian methods and nonparametrics, so he might have a significant focus on those topics.

Michael Jordan, for example, is quite interested in Bayesian methods and nonparametrics, so he might have a significant focus on those topics.

I noticed on the CS Spring 2016 schedule (http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Scheduling/CS/schedule-next.html) CS 281B, Advanced Topics in Learning and Decision Making, is listed, but there doesn't appear to be a course catalog description. Is there anywhere I can look for info about this course? Thanks.
history.subject: CS 281B Spring 2016
